Practice Greenhealth recommends comprehensive waste tracking as a starting point for any healthcare institution looking to improve its environmental footprint. Understanding the breakdown of both cost and weight for different waste categories can be one of the easiest strategies to identify areas of opportunity and low-hanging fruit. Beyond waste data, understanding how waste can be prevented, or shifted from a more environmentally-intensive (and expensive) waste stream to a less environmentally intensive waste stream (e.g., from regulated medical waste into recycling) is key to truly reducing the facility's waste footprint.

Baseline Year:The facility's baseline year is generally the first year the facility started tracking waste data. Some facilities use the first year they applied for an Award. Appendix A Recycling and Universal Waste Totals will be summed at the bottom of this page and will also be automatically entered in the Waste Section of this application.

  • Since the definition of Universal Waste varies by state, Universal Waste totals below will include items that are considered hazardous waste if not recycled, even if they are not technically considered Universal Waste in some states (such as lead aprons, silver from X-ray and electronic wastes).

Helpful Hints
  • Crushed lamps must be removed as hazardous waste by a licensed hazardous waste hauler and CANNOT be counted toward recycling or Universal Waste totals. Learn more at EPA’s Mercury Lamp Drum Top Crusher Study (2006).
  • If you have liquid recycling waste (such as waste solvent or vegetable oil from our kitchen), it is most accurate to use the specific gravity of the waste to calculate tonnage. If you do not have this data, simply enter gallons and it will be converted to tons for you, using an estimated 8.35 pounds per gallon.

This appendix provides a resource or checklist for supply chain and other key departments to identify the purchasing opportunities that can support an organization’s sustainability initiatives. Environmentally preferable purchasing (EPP) is intricately tied to nearly all aspects of sustainability. Purchasing is a key part of the process to achieve success in all areas, including waste reduction and energy efficiency. To facilitate your organization’s sustainability efforts, all of the EPP opportunities in each section of the Partner for Change Award (PFC) application are listed below. The section numbers here correlate with page numbers on the PFC. There is nothing to complete on Appendix B- it is for informational purposes only.

LEADERSHIP


This section of EPP activities pertains to the Leadership page of the application.

1. Specify that the annual report use environmentally preferable paper (such as made with at least 30% post-consumer recycled content, processed chlorine free, and/or FSC certified) and soy-based inks. Preference could be given to printing services that have undertaken sustainability measures within their organizations.
  2. When purchasing visuals to describe organization’s environmental commitment, consider items made from environmentally preferable materials (for example: free of PVC, recyclable or reusable, etc.).

WASTE


This section pertains to the Waste page of the application.
Recycling Program Activities

1. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for:
    1. single stream or commingled recycling services (see sample RFP questions at https://practicegreenhealth.org/gsc/eppspecs).
    2. recycling services for paper.
    3. reycling services for recycling and tracking HIPPA/confidential paper.
    4. recycling services for cardboard and boxboard.
    5. recycling services for general plastics (bags, shrink wrap).
    6. recycling services for medical plastics (irrigation bottles, skin prep solution bottles, trays, overwraps, rigid inserts, blue wrap, tyvek, basins, urinals, bedpans, other admission items, other). Take Back Programs where the suppliers are responsible for recycling are an option in purchasing contracts.
    7. recycling metals (aluminum, steel, other).
    8. recycling precious metals from clinical devices.
    9. recycling, take back, or remanufacture of toner and ink cartridges either through a recycling service, office supply contract, or other service provider.
    10. (or supplier take back program) for recycling of non-hazardous alkaline batteries.
    11. collection of compostable materials.
Waste Reduction Activities

1. When applicable, establish a contract for donating materials, equipment, and furniture that ensures the needs of developing countries are met (refer to Catholic Health Association’s guidance “Assessing & Selecting High-Quality Medical Surplus Recovery Organizations” found at http://www.chausa.org/internationaloutreach/medical-surplus-recovery).
  2. Specify the use of reusable totes or containers for supply delivery to reduce waste and labor for handling. (Refer to the Use Reusables campaign for resources, http://usereusables.org/)
  3. Specify the use of reusable containers instead of disposable ones in contracts using one or more of the following containers: shipping, RMW shipping containers, Pharmacy waste containers, Other)
  4. Specify office duplication equipment is equipped to copy on both sides and equipment is set to default to duplex when installed.
  5. Where applicable, specify Vendors provide spend reports for copy paper on regular basis to measure success of paper reduction efforts.
Regulated Medical Waste

1. Specify that service providers for regulated medical waste report: (1) the tons of RMW treated onsite (even if landfilled) or offsite annually, and (2) the costs associated with this treatment. (Note: do not include weight of reusable sharps containers if applicable)
  2. Specify that service providers for non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste report: (1) the tons of non-hazardous waste treated onsite or offsite annually, and (2) the costs associated with this treatment.
  3. Specify that service providers/licensed haulers for incinerated regulated medical waste report: (1) the tons of incinerated medical waste treated annually, and (2) the costs associated with this treatment.
RMW Reduction/Minimization Strategies

1. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for a reusable sharps container program.
  2. Establish or utilize a GPO service contract to recycle medical sharps.
  3. Establish or utilize a GPO service contract with a third party reprocessor for collection of single use medical devices in patient care areas (beyond OR), including EP/Cath labs.
    1. Specify these services provide reports on the number and weight of devices collected in each of the three areas: Patient rooms, EP/Cath Labs, Other (not OR; OR is included in OR section of application)
  4. Purchase reprocessed single use medical devices from an FDA approved third party reprocessor.
    1. Specify these services provide reports on the number of devices collected and the cost savings in each of the three areas: Patient rooms, EP/Cath Labs, or other outside of the OR.
Hazardous Waste

1. Specify that service providers for collection of RCRA hazardous waste (including solvents, engine oil, Zenker, and B5 stains, lab packs, refrigerants, etc) periodically report: (1) the tons and/or gallons of RCRA hazardous waste annually, and (2) the costs associated with this treatment.
Hazardous Waste Minimization Activities

1. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for recycling services for electronic waste using a certified e-waste service (such as e-Stewards certified). Refer to www.e-stewards.org.
  2. Purchase digital x-ray equipment for radiology to reduce costs of fixer solutions.
  3. When applicable, establish or utilize a GPO contract for recycling services to recycle silver from x-ray films in Radiology.
  4. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for recycling collection services for fluorescent lamps to properly dispose of them ensuring mercury is not released into the environment.
  5. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for recycling batteries or a Vendor take back program to recycle batteries.
  6. When applicable, purchase equipment to recycle, reprocess or distill solvents, alcohols or other chemicals from the lab. Specify that Vendors report gallons handled annually.

CHEMICALS


This section of EPP activities pertains to the Chemicals page of the application.
Policy

1. Adopt a chemical or purchasing policy that addresses one or more of the following chemicals of concern: Mercury, Lead, PBTs, DEHP, PVC, Halogenated Organic Flame Retardants (HFRs), Phthalates, Carcinogens, mutagens and reproductive toxins, BPA, Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), Latex, Halogenated plastics, Perfluorinated compounds, and other chemicals. (See sample purchasing policies at
  2. Specify and purchase paints, adhesives and sealants that have low/no VOCs.
  3. Purchase furniture that has an environmental certification or achieves LEED credits.
Green Cleaning

1. Purchase Green Seal or EcoLogo/UL certified cleaners for the following categories:
    1. General purpose
    2. Window/glass
    3. Carpet and upholstery
    4. Bathroom cleaner
    5. Floor cleaners
    6. Floor strippers
    7. Floor finishes
    8. Laundry Soaps
    9. Hand Soaps
  2. Purchase hand soap with antimicrobials only for areas where it is needed to prevent overuse of antimicrobials.
  3. Purchase powered cleaning equipment labeled by the Carpet and Rug Institute as “CRI Green Label Plus.”
  4. Purchase automatic floor scrubbing machines that use only water for cleaning.
  5. Purchase microfiber mops and cleaning cloths.
  6. Specify in cleaning contracts that suppliers report total spend on “green” cleaners and total spend on other cleaners by cleaning product category.
Sterilization/Disinfection

1. Review during purchasing processes the types of cleaning chemicals needed. Prefer products that don’t require glutaraldehyde for cleaning.
    1. Purchase safer alternatives to glutaraldehyde (such as OPA (ASP Cidex OPA, Metrex Metricide OPA), Hydrogen Peroxide or Other)
  2. Review during purchasing processes/value analysis whether disinfection with glutaraldehyde is required. Prefer alternatives.
  3. Purchase products that don’t require ethylene oxide (EtO) cleaning.
    1. Purchase safer alternatives to EtO (such as Steam Sterilization, Ozone plasma (3M Optreoz with TSO3 Sterizone technology), Low temperature hydrogen peroxide gas plasma (Sterrad), Peracetic Acid (Steris 1 or 1E).
  4. Review during purchasing processes/value analysis whether or not disinfection with ethylene oxide (EtO) is required. Prefer alternatives.
  5. Purchase automatic washers/disinfectors (not manual) to minimize staff exposure to high level disinfection.
Integrated Pest Management

1. Develop or utilize a GPO contract for and purchase services from an Integrated Pest Management Service.
  2. Specify pest control services are certified by GreenShield, EcoWise (CA only) or GreenPro.
DEHP and PVC

1. Purchase PVC-free products, including medical products and construction/renovation materials.
  2. Purchase PVC/DEHP-free products from at least one product category:
    1. Enteral nutrition products
    2. Parenteral infusion devices and sets
    3. General urological sets and solutions, catheters)
    4. Exam gloves
    5. Umbilical vessel catheters
    6. Vascular catheters
    7. Other
  3. Purchase PVC/DEHP-free products in the NICU.
Other Chemical Reduction

1. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for a hazardous chemicals/materials audit by each hospital department (or perform internally).
  2. Purchase smaller sized supplies (i.e., specialized pipettes and glassware) to perform chemical experiments based on “microscale chemistry,” which reduces the use of chemicals to the lowest level at which experiments can be effectively performed.
  3. Review in purchasing processes opportunities to select medical products free of chemicals of concern (ex. mattresses, draperies, positioners, etc). (See Practice Greenhealth’s EPP Specifications and Resources Guide or ask questions as provided in the Standardized Environmental Questions for Medical Products, v 1.0)
  4. Specify suppliers provide purchasing reports on products purchased without specified chemicals of concern.
  5. Purchase or specify products free of intentionally added chemicals of concern.
Mercury

1. Specify proper mercury disposal in the template for demolition contracts.
  2. Specify mercury-free materials in the template for building and construction contracts.
Clinical

1. Specify all mercury-containing products must be labeled on the device.
  2. Purchase mercury-free patient thermometers.
  3. Purchase 90% or more blood pressure devices (sphygmomanometers) that are mercury-free.
  4. Purchase 90% or more clinical devices (bougies, miller-abbott tubes, cantor tubes, dilators) that are mercury-free.
  5. Purchase and install mercury amalgam separators for all dental chairs.
Laboratory
1. Specify and purchase mercury-free lab thermometers, solutions and other equipment where possible.

GREENING THE OR


This section pertains to the Greening the OR page of the application.
Waste Segregation and Management

1. Purchase fluid suction management system using reusable canisters and empties into the sanitary sewer system.
    1. Require supplier provide reports to track: (1) Avoided waste costs, (2) Avoided purchase costs of disposable canisters, (2) Avoided purchase costs of chemical solidifiers.
  2. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for recycling services for medical plastics in the OR that may include rigid plastics of various sizes, soft plastics, empty bottles, blue wrap, clean tyvek, and/or other materials.
    1. Require supplier report on volume of plastics recycled in the OR.
Waste Reduction in the OR

1. Reformulate/review the purchase of custom OR Kits to reduce waste and save money (such as by removing supplies not typically used, by removing excess supplies).
    1. Track number of kits reviewed/reformulated; track number of items removed; supply savings; avoided waste disposal savings.
  2. Purchase pre-drawn syringes to minimize pharmaceutical waste costs.
  3. Purchase small pharmaceutical containers to minimize waste costs.
  4. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for collection services for FDA-approved single-use medical device reprocessing.
    1. Specify supplier report number of devices collected, weight of devices (tons).
  5. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for purchasing reprocessed single use devices from an FDA-approved third-party reprocessor.
    1. Specify supplier report on the number of devices purchased and savings by purchasing reprocessed devices.
  6. Purchase reusable surgical items:
    1. Linens: Surgical gowns, Back table covers, Mayo stand covers, Surgical drapes, Surgical towels
    2. Other: Anesthesia Circuits, Endotracheal tubes, Grounding pads, Surgical basins, Laryngoscope Mask Airways (LMA), Trocar, Patient Positioning devices, and other
  7. Purchase reusable hard cases for sterilization of surgical instrumentation.
    1. Require supplier report on number of kits purchased, avoided spend on blue wrap.
  8. Purchase microfiber mops in the OR.
Energy Management

1. Purchase HVAC system that complies with ASHRAE 170 guidance for air exchanges per hour in the OR.
  2. Purchase LED surgical lighting for the OR.
    1. Require supplier report avoided energy use, supply cost or avoided labor as applicable.
  3. Purchase occupancy sensors for the OR.
Anesthesia Gas/Greenhouse Gas Emissions

1. Purchase a waste anesthetic gas capturing system.
  2. Purchase intravenous or neuraxial blocks as an alternative to inhaled agents.
  3. Specify in applicable gas contracts that during maintenance to reduce fresh gas flows in order to reduce unnecessary anesthetic gas use.

FOOD


This section peratins to the FOOD page of the application.
Food and Beverage Environment

1. Purchase healthy beverages.
    1. Examples include: Water (filtered tap, unsweetened, 100% fruit-infused, seltzer or flavored); 100% fruit juice (optimal 4oz serving); 100% vegetable juice (optimal sodium less than 140 mg); Milk (unflavored); Non-dairy milk alternatives (unsweetened); Teas and Coffee (unsweetened with only naturally occurring caffeine). Beverages should be locally- sourced, sustainably-produced and Organic when possible (See Definitions for Local/Sustainable). Beverages should be dispensed by tap or fountain AND reusable beverage containers should be encouraged when possible.
Local and Sustainably Produced Food Purchasing

1. Contract for local (within 250 mile radius) and/or sustainably grown and produced food. Track percentage of dollars spent on food and beverages purchased that meets this criteria compared to all food and beverages purchased.
Hospital Supported Agriculture: Food and Farm Linkages

1. Coordinate with local family managed or owned farm(s) to match planting decisions with purchasing intentions prior to growing season.
  2. Communicate with distributor and GPO about sourcing local foods and encourage them to improve tracking and traceability of these foods in their ordering, invoicing and reporting systems.
Food Waste Reduction

1. Purchase reusable food service ware for cafeteria/retail and patient meals.
  2. Purchase biobased food service ware for cafeteria/retail and patient meals.
  3. Purchase certified commercially compostable food ware for cafeteria/retail and patient meals.
  4. Purchase items for food service that are not made from polystyrene (Styrofoam®) (such as plates, cups).
  5. Purchase bulk beverages (as opposed to single use bottles).

ENVIRONMENTALLY PREFERABLE PURCHASING (EPP)


This section pertains to the EPP page of the application.
Infrastructure for EPP

1. Engage with supply chain leadership on sustainability activities.
  2. Ask C-Suite Representatives or Facility Senior Leadership to sign the Practice Greenhealth EPP Pledge.
  3. Adopt EPP purchasing policies or incorporate EPP into purchasing procedural manuals and identify specific attributes of concern when making purchasing decisions including one or more of the following:
    1. Energy efficiency, water efficiency, excessive packaging, recycled content, recyclability, avoiding chemicals of concern, reusables, waste minimization, reducing hazardous waste generation, addressing end of life management, and green building products.
  4. Outline EPP implementation strategies in policy or other resource.
  5. Define EPP roles and responsibilities in policy, job descriptions, or other resource.
Contracting for EPP

1. Communicate with your GPO regarding support for environmentally preferable products.
  2. Have a process to include environmental specifications or RFP questions in bids or utilize GPO provided environmental information.
  3. Specify in contract templates and other supplier outreach materials the organization’s commitment to environmentally preferable purchasing.
  4. Track and report metrics regarding what is spent for environmentally preferable products.
  5. Communicate with supply chain staff about the Standardized Environmental Questions for Medical Products.
  6. Purchase the following product types:
    1. EPEAT registered computers, monitors and laptops
    2. EPEAT registered imaging equipment (copiers, printers, multifunctional devices)
    3. EPEAT registered televisions
    4. Janitorial paper supplies with postconsumer recycled content
  7. Identify the most innovative and/or most successful environmentally preferable purchasing projects.

ENERGY


This section pertains to the Energy page of the application.
Energy Use

1. Purchase renewable energy and track annual consumption.
      2. Based on the US Green Building Council’s definition, valid renewable energy systems are: Photovoltaic systems; solar thermal systems; bio-fuel based electrical systems (untreated wood waste mill residues, agricultural crops or waste); animal waste and other organic waste and landfill gas; geothermal heating systems; geothermal electric systems ; low-impact hydroelectric power systems and wave and tidal power systems.
  2. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for buying/ selling Renewable Energy Credits.
  3. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for services to develop a Strategic Energy Master Plan (SEMP).
  4. Establish or utilize a GP contract for services with a retro commissioning firm to optimize building performance.
  5. Purchase submeters for measuring energy efficiency opportunities.
  6. Purchase energy efficient equipment that is Energy Star certified or EPEAT registered.
  7. Purchase at least 3 energy efficient products and track dollars spent.

1. Establish or utilize a GPO contract for services to perform water use audits.
  2. Specify in landscape design contracts for landscape methods that reduce water use and/or eliminate irrigation.
  3. Specify EPA WaterSense labeled products for at least three products/devices and track dollars spent.

CLIMATE


This section pertains to the Climate page of the application.
1. When applicable, establish or utilize a GPO contract for services to perform a Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Audit.
Transportation

1. Purchase alternative fueled vehicles for fleet. Alternative fuels include: Biodiesel B20-B100, Electricity, E8 Ethanol, Hydrogen, Methanol, Natural Gas, Propane, P-Series (a family of renewable, non-petroleum, liquid fuels that can substitute for gasoline).

GREEN BUILDING

Infrastructure for Green Design and Construction

1. Specify green/sustainable aspects in Master Construction documents for all new buildings/renovations.
